issue.title: `new_messages()` returns wrong results when history processors prune messages from current run

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Report that something isn't working, or PR implementing a fix

issue.body:
### Initial Checks

- [x] I'm using the [latest version](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/releases/latest) of Pydantic AI
- [x] I've searched for my issue in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues) before opening this issue

### Description

## Bug

When a history processor removes messages created during the current run, `new_messages()` returns incorrect results. The internal `new_message_index` becomes negative, causing Python's negative indexing to silently return a subset of messages instead of all new messages.

**Expected:** `new_messages()` returns all messages created during this run.
**Actual:** Returns only the last N messages (where N depends on how many were pruned).

## Example

Starting fresh with `new_message_index = 0` and a history processor that keeps only the last 4 messages.

**After 6 messages (pruning kicks in):**
```python
message_history = [new1, new2, new3, new4, new5, new6]
new_message_index = 0
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new3, new4, new5, new6]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = 0 - (6-4) = -2

new_messages() = message_history[-2:] = [new5, new6]  ✗ (should be all 6)
```

**After 8 messages:**
```python
message_history = [new3, new4, new5, new6, new7, new8]
new_message_index = -2
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new5, new6, new7, new8]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = -2 - (6-4) = -4

new_messages() = message_history[-4:] = [new5, new6, new7, new8]  ✗
```

The index keeps decreasing: `0 → -2 → -4 → -6 → ...`

## Impact

The documented pattern is to use `new_messages()` to get messages from the current run and append them to your own copy of the history. When `new_messages()` returns incorrect results, there's no reliable way to know which messages are new - they don't have unique IDs and the length of `new_messages()` is non-monotonic.

## Root cause

The adjustment at `_agent_graph.py:495` assumes history processors only remove "old" messages from previous runs:

```python
new_message_index -= len(history_before_processing) - len(history_after_processing)
```

When processors remove messages from the current run, this overshoots and makes the index negative. There's no bounds checking here or in `run.py:160` where `new_messages()` uses the index.

## Reproduction

See attached script that demonstrates the issue with a `keep_last_4` history processor and a `FunctionModel`.


### Minimal, Reproducible Example

```Python
"""
Minimal reproduction: new_message_index goes negative with history processors.

When a history_processor removes messages added during the CURRENT run,
new_message_index goes negative. This causes new_messages() to use
Python negative indexing, returning wrong results.

Run with: uv run python pydantic-ai-new-message-index-bug.py
"""

import asyncio

from pydantic_ai import Agent, RunContext
from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelMessage, ModelResponse, ToolCallPart, TextPart
from pydantic_ai.models.function import AgentInfo, FunctionModel


def keep_last_4(messages: list[ModelMessage]) -> list[ModelMessage]:
    """Keep only last 4 messages."""
    return messages[-4:] if len(messages) > 4 else messages


call_count = 0


async def mock_model(messages: list[ModelMessage], info: AgentInfo) -> ModelResponse:
    global call_count
    call_count += 1
    if call_count < 5:
        return ModelResponse(parts=[ToolCallPart(tool_name="my_tool", args={"i": call_count})])
    return ModelResponse(parts=[TextPart(content="done")])


agent = Agent(
    model=FunctionModel(mock_model),
    history_processors=[keep_last_4],
)


@agent.tool
async def my_tool(ctx: RunContext[None], i: int) -> str:
    return f"ok-{i}"


def summarize_message(msg: ModelMessage) -> str:
    """One-line summary of a message."""
    from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelRequest
    parts = []
    for p in msg.parts:
        name = type(p).__name__
        if hasattr(p, "args"):
            parts.append(f"{name}({p.args})")
        elif hasattr(p, "content"):
            content = p.content[:20] if isinstance(p.content, str) else p.content
            parts.append(f"{name}({content!r})")
        else:
            parts.append(name)
    kind = "Req" if isinstance(msg, ModelRequest) else "Resp"
    return f"{kind}[{', '.join(parts)}]"


async def main():
    async with agent.iter(user_prompt="go") as run:
        async for node in run:
            idx = run.ctx.deps.new_message_index
            all_msgs = run.all_messages()
            new_msgs = run.new_messages()
            all_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in all_msgs)
            new_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in new_msgs)
            print(f"\n{type(node).__name__:20} new_message_index={idx}")
            print(f"  all_messages ({len(all_msgs)}): [{all_summary}]")
            print(f"  new_messages ({len(new_msgs)}): [{new_summary}]")


asyncio.run(main())
```

### Logfire Trace

_No response_

### Python, Pydantic AI & LLM client version

- Python: 3.12
- Pydantic AI: 1.41.0
- LLM provider SDK: Anthropic (not relevant)

issue.title: Bug: Agent Incorrectly Resumes Session for Fresh Executions

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
# Bug: Agent Incorrectly Resumes Session for Fresh Executions

## Description

When running Heimdall with a fresh session, the agent incorrectly reports "Resumed session" and loads state from a previous execution, even though the user did not request to resume.

## Reproduction Steps

1. Run Heimdall with persistence enabled (default when using `--output`):
   ```bash
   python -m heimdall.cli run instructions.txt --demo
   ```

2. Observe the log output shows:
   ```
   INFO     Resumed session 21fefa8e at step 71
   ```

3. This occurs even though:
   - No explicit resume flag was provided
   - This is a fresh execution (not a continuation)
   - The previous session was from a different run

## Expected Behavior

- Fresh executions should start from step 0 with a new session ID
- "Resumed session" should only appear when:
  - The user explicitly chooses to resume after a `Ctrl+C` pause
  - A clear resume flag/option is provided
  - The saved state is from a very recent session (e.g., within the last hour)

## Actual Behavior

- Agent loads state from any previous execution with the same task string
- Session continues from the saved step count
- No way to start fresh without manually deleting `.heimdall_state.json`

## Root Cause Analysis

The bug is in [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py#L203-L233):

```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:  # ← ISSUE HERE
            self._session_id = persisted.session_id
            # ... restore state ...
            restored = True
            logger.info(
                f"Resumed session {self._session_id} at step {self._state.step_count}"
            )
```

### Problems

1. **Overly permissive matching**: The condition `persisted.task == task and not persisted.done` will match ANY previous execution with the same task string, regardless of:
   - When it was run (could be from days ago)
   - Whether it was paused intentionally or crashed
   - Whether the user intends to resume

2. **No explicit resume intent**: There's no mechanism for the user to indicate they want to resume vs. start fresh

3. **Missing staleness check**: Old saved states should be ignored or require explicit confirmation

4. **Paused state ignored**: The saved state has `paused: true`, but this field is not checked. Only intentionally paused sessions should be auto-resumed.

## Evidence

Saved state file content (`output/.heimdall_state.json`):
```json
{
  "session_id": "21fefa8e",
  "task": "Start replying until you reply to 10 different posts and only post replies nothing else",
  "step_count": 75,
  "done": false,
  "success": false,
  "paused": true,
  "started_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977943",
  "paused_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977833"
}
```

This state from a previous run is being restored even though it's from a different execution.

## Proposed Solutions

### Option 1: Add Explicit Resume Flag (Recommended)

Add a `--resume` CLI flag that must be explicitly set to resume from saved state:

**CLI changes** (`src/heimdall/cli.py`):
```python
@app.command()
def run(
    # ... existing args ...
    resume: bool = typer.Option(False, "--resume", help="Resume from saved state if available"),
)
```

**Agent config** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:AgentConfig`):
```python
class AgentConfig(BaseModel):
    # ... existing fields ...
    allow_resume: bool = False  # Only resume if explicitly allowed
```

**Resume logic** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`):
```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._config.allow_resume  # ← NEW: Require explicit opt-in
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
            # ... restore state ...
```

### Option 2: Time-Based Auto-Resume

Only auto-resume if the saved state is very recent (e.g., within last hour):

```python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Check if state is recent
    paused_time = datetime.fromisoformat(persisted.paused_at)
    time_since_pause = datetime.now() - paused_time
    
    if time_since_pause < timedelta(hours=1):
        # Auto-resume recent paused sessions
        restored = True
    else:
        # Ask user or start fresh
        logger.info(f"Found paused session from {time_since_pause.total_seconds()/3600:.1f} hours ago")
        logger.info("Use --resume flag to continue from saved state")
```

### Option 3: Interactive Prompt

Prompt the user when saved state is found:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:
    from rich.console import Console
    console = Console()
    
    resume = console.input(
        f"Found saved session at step {persisted.step_count}. Resume? [y/N]: "
    )
    
    if resume.lower() == 'y':
        restored = True
```

## Recommended Fix

Implement **Option 1** (explicit `--resume` flag) because:
- Most predictable behavior for users
- Allows both workflows (fresh start vs. resume) to coexist
- No surprising auto-resume behavior
- Still supports pause/resume within a single execution via `Ctrl+C`

Additionally, add a check for `persisted.paused` to ensure only intentionally paused sessions are eligible for resume:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Only resume paused sessions, not crashed/failed ones
```

## Additional Context

- Persistence is currently always enabled when using `--output` (line 228 in `cli.py`)
- The pause/resume feature using `Ctrl+C` works correctly within a single execution
- The issue only affects cross-execution state restoration

## Related Files

- [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py) - Agent execution loop with resume logic
- [`src/heimdall/persistence/state.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/persistence/state.py) - State management
- [`src/heimdall/cli.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/cli.py) - CLI interface

## Environment

- OS: macOS
- Heimdall version: Latest (from repo)
- Python version: 3.12

The bug is in [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py#L203-L233):

```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:  # ← ISSUE HERE
            self._session_id = persisted.session_id
            # ... restore state ...
            restored = True
            logger.info(
                f"Resumed session {self._session_id} at step {self._state.step_count}"
            )
```

### Problems

1. **Overly permissive matching**: The condition `persisted.task == task and not persisted.done` will match ANY previous execution with the same task string, regardless of:
   - When it was run (could be from days ago)
   - Whether it was paused intentionally or crashed
   - Whether the user intends to resume

2. **No explicit resume intent**: There's no mechanism for the user to indicate they want to resume vs. start fresh

3. **Missing staleness check**: Old saved states should be ignored or require explicit confirmation

4. **Paused state ignored**: The saved state has `paused: true`, but this field is not checked. Only intentionally paused sessions should be auto-resumed.

## Evidence

Saved state file content (`output/.heimdall_state.json`):
```json
{
  "session_id": "21fefa8e",
  "task": "Start replying until you reply to 10 different posts and only post replies nothing else",
  "step_count": 75,
  "done": false,
  "success": false,
  "paused": true,
  "started_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977943",
  "paused_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977833"
}
```

This state from a previous run is being restored even though it's from a different execution.

## Proposed Solutions

### Option 1: Add Explicit Resume Flag (Recommended)

Add a `--resume` CLI flag that must be explicitly set to resume from saved state:

**CLI changes** (`src/heimdall/cli.py`):
```python
@app.command()
def run(
    # ... existing args ...
    resume: bool = typer.Option(False, "--resume", help="Resume from saved state if available"),
)
```

**Agent config** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:AgentConfig`):
```python
class AgentConfig(BaseModel):
    # ... existing fields ...
    allow_resume: bool = False  # Only resume if explicitly allowed
```

**Resume logic** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`):
```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._config.allow_resume  # ← NEW: Require explicit opt-in
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
            # ... restore state ...
```

### Option 2: Time-Based Auto-Resume

Only auto-resume if the saved state is very recent (e.g., within last hour):

```python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Check if state is recent
    paused_time = datetime.fromisoformat(persisted.paused_at)
    time_since_pause = datetime.now() - paused_time
    
    if time_since_pause < timedelta(hours=1):
        # Auto-resume recent paused sessions
        restored = True
    else:
        # Ask user or start fresh
        logger.info(f"Found paused session from {time_since_pause.total_seconds()/3600:.1f} hours ago")
        logger.info("Use --resume flag to continue from saved state")
```

### Option 3: Interactive Prompt

Prompt the user when saved state is found:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:
    from rich.console import Console
    console = Console()
    
    resume = console.input(
        f"Found saved session at step {persisted.step_count}. Resume? [y/N]: "
    )
    
    if resume.lower() == 'y':
        restored = True
```

## Recommended Fix

Implement **Option 1** (explicit `--resume` flag) because:
- Most predictable behavior for users
- Allows both workflows (fresh start vs. resume) to coexist
- No surprising auto-resume behavior
- Still supports pause/resume within a single execution via `Ctrl+C`

Additionally, add a check for `persisted.paused` to ensure only intentionally paused sessions are eligible for resume:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Only resume paused sessions, not crashed/failed ones
```

## Additional Context

- Persistence is currently always enabled when using `--output` (line 228 in `cli.py`)
- The pause/resume feature using `Ctrl+C` works correctly within a single execution
- The issue only affects cross-execution state restoration

## Related Files

- [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py) - Agent execution loop with resume logic
- [`src/heimdall/persistence/state.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/persistence/state.py) - State management
- [`src/heimdall/cli.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/cli.py) - CLI interface

comment.body:
Fixed in commit 86aa906

Implemented run_id-based session management with --run-id flag for explicit resume control.

Key improvements:
- Fresh executions default to starting from step 0 (no auto-resume)
- Each run gets a unique 8-char UUID
- State files organized in .heimdall/runs/{run_id}/
- Multiple paused sessions can coexist
- Specific error messages for resume failures

issue.title: Meta: Issue & PR Prioritization in the age of AI-assisted coding

labels.name: meta
labels.description: high level, conceptual

issue.body:
Hey Pydantic AI community!

As you may have noticed, we/I haven't been as quick to respond to issues, review PRs, or release new versions since the holidays, compared to the same-day response/review and one-release-a-day cadence we got used to during 2025.

## Prioritization

Part of the story is that inevitably, as the popularity of an open source project grows, so do the number of notifications that land in its maintainers' GitHub inboxes every day, meaning that last year's "treat every contributor like a colleague and every issue/PR notification like a top priority" approach was never going to be sustainable forever.

We were able to mostly maintain that through the first year of Pydantic AI's existence, and I know that our "extension of your team"-level responsiveness has been much appreciated and (not unimportantly considering that we are a business) a significant factor in converting Pydantic AI users to [Pydantic Logfire](https://pydantic.dev/logfire) customers.

But already by the last few months of the year, it was becoming clear that this user-interrupt-driven approach to prioritization was starting to get in the way of working on more significant improvements and new capabilities that will benefit everyone building agents using Pydantic AI (like [Code Mode](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/4050) (aka Programmatic Tool Calling), [Progressive Tool Disclosure](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/3590) (aka Deferred Tool Loading), [Sub-Agents](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/1978), and [Guardrails](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/1197)), whereas users' issues and PRs typically focus on improving existing features around the edges: the faster horse as opposed to the car.

Thankfully, the community has done an awesome job stepping in to fill the gap with packages like [pydantic-deep](https://github.com/vstorm-co/pydantic-deepagents) and more listed on <https://github.com/vstorm-co/awesome-pydantic-ai> (in line with our preference for providing strong foundations and abstractions like `AbstractToolset` and `AbstractAgent` that people can build on, as opposed to coming with every battery included), but we agree that some of those features should just be in the core framework. (I'm happy to share that we expect to ship Code Mode and Progressive Tool Disclosure in the next week or two!)

This means that we're going to need to implement an (AI-assisted!) process for prioritizing issues and PRs for response and review, more explicitly taking into account factors like the number of users who would benefit, alignment with our vision for the project in project and AI engineering in general, the amount of effort that was put in by the contributor, and the time it will take us to aid them in getting it to the point where we'd be confident merging it and maintaining it indefinitely.

The bottom line is that we're dropping the expectation that every single issue/PR will get human attention, quickly or at all, while making it clear what motivated contributors can do to get their favorite items up the queue. 

I have some ideas on how we can do this that I will share later this week, and I'd love to hear your suggestions as well.

## Impact of AI-assisted coding on open source contributions

"More usage means more issues and PRs" is only half of the story, though, as eloquently pointed out by a user on [an issue](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/3885) created during the holidays that took me much longer to get to than I would've liked:

> "**Is AI actually making y'all slower rather than faster?**"

As someone who's [been working full time on open source developer tools](https://douwe.me/) for the past 10 years, the answer has in recent months unfortunately become "**yes**".

It used to be that it took significantly more effort for a contributor to create a PR or address a round of feedback than it took for a maintainer to review a PR, creating some natural back-pressure on the number of PRs that are requesting a new round of review each day. Similarly, the ratio between new issues and PRs would typically favor the former, at least when it came to new features, as it's much easier to share an idea than to go through the effort of building it -- and most people wouldn't anyway until they'd validated that the maintainer would accept a particular solution.

A single maintainer could arrive to 20 new issues and 10 new PRs on Monday morning, review them all over the course of a few hours, and then expect to have code trickle in throughout the week as contributors found time to incorporate the feedback or start on an issue, plus some amount of new items each day, at a similar rate to other issues/PRs being closed/merged. 

Especially large PRs adding significant new functionality and public APIs, that consume the most time and mental energy to review, would typically be spread out over multiple weeks this way, ensuring both contributor and maintainer spent enough time with it in mind to be confident in the design and implications, and allowing maintainers to juggle them along with (much more numerous) smaller PRs (that would get more frequent updates and reviews) and work they want to prioritize themselves.

Maintainers would also be able to assume that any big PR whose code looked good had significant mental effort put into it by another competent engineer who themselves needed the feature and thus had the necessary context to make design decisions about it, allowing the maintainer to offload some of the mental load on the contributor and juggle more PRs and context switches at the same time. 

Obviously none of that is the case anymore today, meaning that on top of the community of users and contributors growing, the amount of work any given community member can create for the maintainer has been growing quickly as well. (To give you an idea, after the holidays I came back to about 150 new GitHub notifications, more than half of which were PRs in want of review, and most mornings I arrive to 40+ new notifications of which at least 2/3rds are PRs.)

Of course, maintainers can and should also use AI to reduce their review workload by automating (parts of) the code review process and moving various types of project-specific rules and "things only the maintainer knows" from review time to development time through things like `AGENTS.md` and specialized sub-agents, and I'm excited to start implementing those for Pydantic AI as well. 

But at the end of the day, the maintainer remains responsible for every line of code, behavior, and public API that makes it into the project (in a sense, a maintainer owes its users that in return for the trust that they have placed in them by choosing the project as part of their stack), and thus their eyes and brain will remain a bottleneck until that expectation changes (which it very well might in coming years, if all open source code converges to "by AI, for AI").

So in addition to changes we need to make around triage and prioritization in general, I think we need to look into ways to _increase_ the barrier for contribution, in order to:
- ensure that the mental load and sense of responsibility for the changes (especially the behavior and public API) are appropriately shared between the contributor and maintainer,
	- meaning, among other things, that the maintainer can never be the first human to critically read a PR line-by-line -- the contributor has to be the "first line of defense" between the AI and the maintainer, and understand why every line is there in that particular way,
- discourage going straight-to-code on big changes in a well-meaning attempt to be helpful, when:
    - the feature really should've spent some more time in the planning stage (as in: hashing out the details in the issue, likely with help from e.g. Claude Code's plan mode), or when
    - the user was not well suited to implement it as they did not themselves experience the problem or have a need for the solution -- they just wanted to be helpful and/or boost their GitHub numbers.

I have some ideas on that front as well that I will share later this week -- and I'd love to hear your thoughts too.

PS. If you're interested in reading what other open source maintainers have written on the subject, Claude found me these recent discussions on Hacker News:
- ["We need a clearer framework for AI-assisted contributions to open source"](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45731321)
- ["Are open source maintainers going to be the main sufferers from LLM"](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46637295 )
- ["AI and Open Source: A Maintainer's Take"](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46453713  )
- ["AI tooling must be disclosed for contributions"](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/pull/8289)
- ["Agent Psychosis: Are We Going Insane?"](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46666777)
- ["Ghostty: AI Usage Policy"](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=46730504)

comment.body: @DouweM I hope this doesn't restrict people who genuinely want to make valuable contributions.

issue.title: Bug: Agent Incorrectly Resumes Session for Fresh Executions

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
# Bug: Agent Incorrectly Resumes Session for Fresh Executions

## Description

When running Heimdall with a fresh session, the agent incorrectly reports "Resumed session" and loads state from a previous execution, even though the user did not request to resume.

## Reproduction Steps

1. Run Heimdall with persistence enabled (default when using `--output`):
   ```bash
   python -m heimdall.cli run instructions.txt --demo
   ```

2. Observe the log output shows:
   ```
   INFO     Resumed session 21fefa8e at step 71
   ```

3. This occurs even though:
   - No explicit resume flag was provided
   - This is a fresh execution (not a continuation)
   - The previous session was from a different run

## Expected Behavior

- Fresh executions should start from step 0 with a new session ID
- "Resumed session" should only appear when:
  - The user explicitly chooses to resume after a `Ctrl+C` pause
  - A clear resume flag/option is provided
  - The saved state is from a very recent session (e.g., within the last hour)

## Actual Behavior

- Agent loads state from any previous execution with the same task string
- Session continues from the saved step count
- No way to start fresh without manually deleting `.heimdall_state.json`

## Root Cause Analysis

The bug is in [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py#L203-L233):

```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:  # ← ISSUE HERE
            self._session_id = persisted.session_id
            # ... restore state ...
            restored = True
            logger.info(
                f"Resumed session {self._session_id} at step {self._state.step_count}"
            )
```

### Problems

1. **Overly permissive matching**: The condition `persisted.task == task and not persisted.done` will match ANY previous execution with the same task string, regardless of:
   - When it was run (could be from days ago)
   - Whether it was paused intentionally or crashed
   - Whether the user intends to resume

2. **No explicit resume intent**: There's no mechanism for the user to indicate they want to resume vs. start fresh

3. **Missing staleness check**: Old saved states should be ignored or require explicit confirmation

4. **Paused state ignored**: The saved state has `paused: true`, but this field is not checked. Only intentionally paused sessions should be auto-resumed.

## Evidence

Saved state file content (`output/.heimdall_state.json`):
```json
{
  "session_id": "21fefa8e",
  "task": "Start replying until you reply to 10 different posts and only post replies nothing else",
  "step_count": 75,
  "done": false,
  "success": false,
  "paused": true,
  "started_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977943",
  "paused_at": "2026-01-20T10:16:21.977833"
}
```

This state from a previous run is being restored even though it's from a different execution.

## Proposed Solutions

### Option 1: Add Explicit Resume Flag (Recommended)

Add a `--resume` CLI flag that must be explicitly set to resume from saved state:

**CLI changes** (`src/heimdall/cli.py`):
```python
@app.command()
def run(
    # ... existing args ...
    resume: bool = typer.Option(False, "--resume", help="Resume from saved state if available"),
)
```

**Agent config** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:AgentConfig`):
```python
class AgentConfig(BaseModel):
    # ... existing fields ...
    allow_resume: bool = False  # Only resume if explicitly allowed
```

**Resume logic** (`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py:203-233`):
```python
# Try to resume from state if available
restored = False
if (
    self._config.enable_persistence
    and self._config.allow_resume  # ← NEW: Require explicit opt-in
    and self._state_manager
    and self._state_manager.has_saved_state
):
    try:
        persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
        if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
            # ... restore state ...
```

### Option 2: Time-Based Auto-Resume

Only auto-resume if the saved state is very recent (e.g., within last hour):

```python
from datetime import datetime, timedelta

persisted = await self._state_manager.load_state()
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Check if state is recent
    paused_time = datetime.fromisoformat(persisted.paused_at)
    time_since_pause = datetime.now() - paused_time
    
    if time_since_pause < timedelta(hours=1):
        # Auto-resume recent paused sessions
        restored = True
    else:
        # Ask user or start fresh
        logger.info(f"Found paused session from {time_since_pause.total_seconds()/3600:.1f} hours ago")
        logger.info("Use --resume flag to continue from saved state")
```

### Option 3: Interactive Prompt

Prompt the user when saved state is found:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done:
    from rich.console import Console
    console = Console()
    
    resume = console.input(
        f"Found saved session at step {persisted.step_count}. Resume? [y/N]: "
    )
    
    if resume.lower() == 'y':
        restored = True
```

## Recommended Fix

Implement **Option 1** (explicit `--resume` flag) because:
- Most predictable behavior for users
- Allows both workflows (fresh start vs. resume) to coexist
- No surprising auto-resume behavior
- Still supports pause/resume within a single execution via `Ctrl+C`

Additionally, add a check for `persisted.paused` to ensure only intentionally paused sessions are eligible for resume:

```python
if persisted and persisted.task == task and not persisted.done and persisted.paused:
    # Only resume paused sessions, not crashed/failed ones
```

## Additional Context

- Persistence is currently always enabled when using `--output` (line 228 in `cli.py`)
- The pause/resume feature using `Ctrl+C` works correctly within a single execution
- The issue only affects cross-execution state restoration

## Related Files

- [`src/heimdall/agent/loop.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/agent/loop.py) - Agent execution loop with resume logic
- [`src/heimdall/persistence/state.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/persistence/state.py) - State management
- [`src/heimdall/cli.py`](file:///Users/black/Documents/repo/heimdall/src/heimdall/cli.py) - CLI interface

## Environment

- OS: macOS
- Heimdall version: Latest (from repo)
- Python version: 3.12

## Changes

- Changed service schedule from interval-based (every 12 hours) to cron-based (daily at 00:01)
- More predictable wallpaper updates at midnight
- Updated both main repo and homebrew-tap formulas

## Installation

```bash
brew install madanlalit/tap/progress
brew services start progress
```

The wallpaper will now update daily at 00:01 AM.

issue.title: `new_messages()` returns wrong results when history processors prune messages from current run

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Report that something isn't working, or PR implementing a fix

issue.body:
### Initial Checks

- [x] I'm using the [latest version](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/releases/latest) of Pydantic AI
- [x] I've searched for my issue in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues) before opening this issue

### Description

## Bug

When a history processor removes messages created during the current run, `new_messages()` returns incorrect results. The internal `new_message_index` becomes negative, causing Python's negative indexing to silently return a subset of messages instead of all new messages.

**Expected:** `new_messages()` returns all messages created during this run.
**Actual:** Returns only the last N messages (where N depends on how many were pruned).

## Example

Starting fresh with `new_message_index = 0` and a history processor that keeps only the last 4 messages.

**After 6 messages (pruning kicks in):**
```python
message_history = [new1, new2, new3, new4, new5, new6]
new_message_index = 0
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new3, new4, new5, new6]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = 0 - (6-4) = -2

new_messages() = message_history[-2:] = [new5, new6]  ✗ (should be all 6)
```

**After 8 messages:**
```python
message_history = [new3, new4, new5, new6, new7, new8]
new_message_index = -2
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new5, new6, new7, new8]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = -2 - (6-4) = -4

new_messages() = message_history[-4:] = [new5, new6, new7, new8]  ✗
```

The index keeps decreasing: `0 → -2 → -4 → -6 → ...`

## Impact

The documented pattern is to use `new_messages()` to get messages from the current run and append them to your own copy of the history. When `new_messages()` returns incorrect results, there's no reliable way to know which messages are new - they don't have unique IDs and the length of `new_messages()` is non-monotonic.

## Root cause

The adjustment at `_agent_graph.py:495` assumes history processors only remove "old" messages from previous runs:

```python
new_message_index -= len(history_before_processing) - len(history_after_processing)
```

When processors remove messages from the current run, this overshoots and makes the index negative. There's no bounds checking here or in `run.py:160` where `new_messages()` uses the index.

## Reproduction

See attached script that demonstrates the issue with a `keep_last_4` history processor and a `FunctionModel`.


### Minimal, Reproducible Example

```Python
"""
Minimal reproduction: new_message_index goes negative with history processors.

When a history_processor removes messages added during the CURRENT run,
new_message_index goes negative. This causes new_messages() to use
Python negative indexing, returning wrong results.

Run with: uv run python pydantic-ai-new-message-index-bug.py
"""

import asyncio

from pydantic_ai import Agent, RunContext
from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelMessage, ModelResponse, ToolCallPart, TextPart
from pydantic_ai.models.function import AgentInfo, FunctionModel


def keep_last_4(messages: list[ModelMessage]) -> list[ModelMessage]:
    """Keep only last 4 messages."""
    return messages[-4:] if len(messages) > 4 else messages


call_count = 0


async def mock_model(messages: list[ModelMessage], info: AgentInfo) -> ModelResponse:
    global call_count
    call_count += 1
    if call_count < 5:
        return ModelResponse(parts=[ToolCallPart(tool_name="my_tool", args={"i": call_count})])
    return ModelResponse(parts=[TextPart(content="done")])


agent = Agent(
    model=FunctionModel(mock_model),
    history_processors=[keep_last_4],
)


@agent.tool
async def my_tool(ctx: RunContext[None], i: int) -> str:
    return f"ok-{i}"


def summarize_message(msg: ModelMessage) -> str:
    """One-line summary of a message."""
    from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelRequest
    parts = []
    for p in msg.parts:
        name = type(p).__name__
        if hasattr(p, "args"):
            parts.append(f"{name}({p.args})")
        elif hasattr(p, "content"):
            content = p.content[:20] if isinstance(p.content, str) else p.content
            parts.append(f"{name}({content!r})")
        else:
            parts.append(name)
    kind = "Req" if isinstance(msg, ModelRequest) else "Resp"
    return f"{kind}[{', '.join(parts)}]"


async def main():
    async with agent.iter(user_prompt="go") as run:
        async for node in run:
            idx = run.ctx.deps.new_message_index
            all_msgs = run.all_messages()
            new_msgs = run.new_messages()
            all_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in all_msgs)
            new_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in new_msgs)
            print(f"\n{type(node).__name__:20} new_message_index={idx}")
            print(f"  all_messages ({len(all_msgs)}): [{all_summary}]")
            print(f"  new_messages ({len(new_msgs)}): [{new_summary}]")


asyncio.run(main())
```

### Logfire Trace

_No response_

### Python, Pydantic AI & LLM client version

- Python: 3.12
- Pydantic AI: 1.41.0
- LLM provider SDK: Anthropic (not relevant)

issue.title: Add You.com as a web search tool

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature request, or PR implementing a feature (enhancement)

issue.body:
### Description

The You.com Search API delivers highly recent and relevant, structured **web** and **news** results optimized for programmatic access. Designed for developers building AI applications like RAG systems, AI agents, knowledge bases, and data-driven applications. Our Search API returns clean, structured data with rich metadata, relevant snippets, and optional full-page content. Learn more here: https://docs.you.com/search/overview

Similar to DuckDuckGo and Tavily, we'd love to make [You.com's](https://you.com/apis) search technology available to developers via Pydantic AI.

Similar to perplexity or chatgpt + web search, we have a consumer product that grounds LLM responses in our search results. Try it out for free at [you.com](https://you.com/)!
 
related PR, adding Tavily: https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/pull/1001
related issue: https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/911

In a world where it is increasingly important to build applications that are highly aware of the world around us, we think that developers on your platform will find a lot of utility in our Search + other APIs. This is a priority for us - please let me know what I can do to help build this. I'm also happy to use the other PRs as references and open one myself! Thanks for reading 🙏🏽 

### References

_No response_

+
+
+def test_create_web_app_with_custom_cdn_url():

issue.title: Add You.com as a web search tool

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature request, or PR implementing a feature (enhancement)

issue.body:
### Description

The You.com Search API delivers highly recent and relevant, structured **web** and **news** results optimized for programmatic access. Designed for developers building AI applications like RAG systems, AI agents, knowledge bases, and data-driven applications. Our Search API returns clean, structured data with rich metadata, relevant snippets, and optional full-page content. Learn more here: https://docs.you.com/search/overview

Similar to DuckDuckGo and Tavily, we'd love to make [You.com's](https://you.com/apis) search technology available to developers via Pydantic AI.

Similar to perplexity or chatgpt + web search, we have a consumer product that grounds LLM responses in our search results. Try it out for free at [you.com](https://you.com/)!
 
related PR, adding Tavily: https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/pull/1001
related issue: https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues/911

In a world where it is increasingly important to build applications that are highly aware of the world around us, we think that developers on your platform will find a lot of utility in our Search + other APIs. This is a priority for us - please let me know what I can do to help build this. I'm also happy to use the other PRs as references and open one myself! Thanks for reading 🙏🏽 

### References

issue.title: `new_messages()` returns wrong results when history processors prune messages from current run

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Report that something isn't working, or PR implementing a fix

issue.body:
### Initial Checks

- [x] I'm using the [latest version](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/releases/latest) of Pydantic AI
- [x] I've searched for my issue in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues) before opening this issue

### Description

## Bug

When a history processor removes messages created during the current run, `new_messages()` returns incorrect results. The internal `new_message_index` becomes negative, causing Python's negative indexing to silently return a subset of messages instead of all new messages.

**Expected:** `new_messages()` returns all messages created during this run.
**Actual:** Returns only the last N messages (where N depends on how many were pruned).

## Example

Starting fresh with `new_message_index = 0` and a history processor that keeps only the last 4 messages.

**After 6 messages (pruning kicks in):**
```python
message_history = [new1, new2, new3, new4, new5, new6]
new_message_index = 0
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new3, new4, new5, new6]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = 0 - (6-4) = -2

new_messages() = message_history[-2:] = [new5, new6]  ✗ (should be all 6)
```

**After 8 messages:**
```python
message_history = [new3, new4, new5, new6, new7, new8]
new_message_index = -2
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new5, new6, new7, new8]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = -2 - (6-4) = -4

new_messages() = message_history[-4:] = [new5, new6, new7, new8]  ✗
```

The index keeps decreasing: `0 → -2 → -4 → -6 → ...`

## Impact

The documented pattern is to use `new_messages()` to get messages from the current run and append them to your own copy of the history. When `new_messages()` returns incorrect results, there's no reliable way to know which messages are new - they don't have unique IDs and the length of `new_messages()` is non-monotonic.

## Root cause

The adjustment at `_agent_graph.py:495` assumes history processors only remove "old" messages from previous runs:

```python
new_message_index -= len(history_before_processing) - len(history_after_processing)
```

When processors remove messages from the current run, this overshoots and makes the index negative. There's no bounds checking here or in `run.py:160` where `new_messages()` uses the index.

## Reproduction

See attached script that demonstrates the issue with a `keep_last_4` history processor and a `FunctionModel`.


### Minimal, Reproducible Example

```Python
"""
Minimal reproduction: new_message_index goes negative with history processors.

When a history_processor removes messages added during the CURRENT run,
new_message_index goes negative. This causes new_messages() to use
Python negative indexing, returning wrong results.

Run with: uv run python pydantic-ai-new-message-index-bug.py
"""

import asyncio

from pydantic_ai import Agent, RunContext
from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelMessage, ModelResponse, ToolCallPart, TextPart
from pydantic_ai.models.function import AgentInfo, FunctionModel


def keep_last_4(messages: list[ModelMessage]) -> list[ModelMessage]:
    """Keep only last 4 messages."""
    return messages[-4:] if len(messages) > 4 else messages


call_count = 0


async def mock_model(messages: list[ModelMessage], info: AgentInfo) -> ModelResponse:
    global call_count
    call_count += 1
    if call_count < 5:
        return ModelResponse(parts=[ToolCallPart(tool_name="my_tool", args={"i": call_count})])
    return ModelResponse(parts=[TextPart(content="done")])


agent = Agent(
    model=FunctionModel(mock_model),
    history_processors=[keep_last_4],
)


@agent.tool
async def my_tool(ctx: RunContext[None], i: int) -> str:
    return f"ok-{i}"


def summarize_message(msg: ModelMessage) -> str:
    """One-line summary of a message."""
    from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelRequest
    parts = []
    for p in msg.parts:
        name = type(p).__name__
        if hasattr(p, "args"):
            parts.append(f"{name}({p.args})")
        elif hasattr(p, "content"):
            content = p.content[:20] if isinstance(p.content, str) else p.content
            parts.append(f"{name}({content!r})")
        else:
            parts.append(name)
    kind = "Req" if isinstance(msg, ModelRequest) else "Resp"
    return f"{kind}[{', '.join(parts)}]"


async def main():
    async with agent.iter(user_prompt="go") as run:
        async for node in run:
            idx = run.ctx.deps.new_message_index
            all_msgs = run.all_messages()
            new_msgs = run.new_messages()
            all_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in all_msgs)
            new_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in new_msgs)
            print(f"\n{type(node).__name__:20} new_message_index={idx}")
            print(f"  all_messages ({len(all_msgs)}): [{all_summary}]")
            print(f"  new_messages ({len(new_msgs)}): [{new_summary}]")


asyncio.run(main())
```

### Logfire Trace

_No response_

### Python, Pydantic AI & LLM client version

- Python: 3.12
- Pydantic AI: 1.41.0
- LLM provider SDK: Anthropic (not relevant)

comment.body:
@DouweM  

Since a run_id is automatically attached to every ModelMessage (requests, responses, and tool calls) generated by the agent, the standard execution flow is already covered.

The critical edge case arises when a history_processor creates and returns entirely new ModelMessage objects that do not have a run_id.

Our options are:

- Enforce run_id as a required field (a breaking change).
- Automatically map the current run_id to orphaned messages (non-breaking solution).

**After 8 messages:**

```python
message_history = [new3, new4, new5, new6, new7, new8]
new_message_index = -2
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new5, new6, new7, new8]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = -2 - (6-4) = -4

new_messages() = message_history[-4:] = [new5, new6, new7, new8]  ✗
```

The index keeps decreasing: `0 → -2 → -4 → -6 → ...`

## Impact

The documented pattern is to use `new_messages()` to get messages from the current run and append them to your own copy of the history. When `new_messages()` returns incorrect results, there's no reliable way to know which messages are new - they don't have unique IDs and the length of `new_messages()` is non-monotonic.

## Root cause

The adjustment at `_agent_graph.py:495` assumes history processors only remove "old" messages from previous runs:

```python
new_message_index -= len(history_before_processing) - len(history_after_processing)
```

When processors remove messages from the current run, this overshoots and makes the index negative. There's no bounds checking here or in `run.py:160` where `new_messages()` uses the index.

## Reproduction

See attached script that demonstrates the issue with a `keep_last_4` history processor and a `FunctionModel`.


### Minimal, Reproducible Example

```Python
"""
Minimal reproduction: new_message_index goes negative with history processors.

When a history_processor removes messages added during the CURRENT run,
new_message_index goes negative. This causes new_messages() to use
Python negative indexing, returning wrong results.

Run with: uv run python pydantic-ai-new-message-index-bug.py
"""

import asyncio

from pydantic_ai import Agent, RunContext
from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelMessage, ModelResponse, ToolCallPart, TextPart
from pydantic_ai.models.function import AgentInfo, FunctionModel


def keep_last_4(messages: list[ModelMessage]) -> list[ModelMessage]:
    """Keep only last 4 messages."""
    return messages[-4:] if len(messages) > 4 else messages


call_count = 0


async def mock_model(messages: list[ModelMessage], info: AgentInfo) -> ModelResponse:
    global call_count
    call_count += 1
    if call_count < 5:
        return ModelResponse(parts=[ToolCallPart(tool_name="my_tool", args={"i": call_count})])
    return ModelResponse(parts=[TextPart(content="done")])


agent = Agent(
    model=FunctionModel(mock_model),
    history_processors=[keep_last_4],
)


@agent.tool
async def my_tool(ctx: RunContext[None], i: int) -> str:
    return f"ok-{i}"


def summarize_message(msg: ModelMessage) -> str:
    """One-line summary of a message."""
    from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelRequest
    parts = []
    for p in msg.parts:
        name = type(p).__name__
        if hasattr(p, "args"):
            parts.append(f"{name}({p.args})")
        elif hasattr(p, "content"):
            content = p.content[:20] if isinstance(p.content, str) else p.content
            parts.append(f"{name}({content!r})")
        else:
            parts.append(name)
    kind = "Req" if isinstance(msg, ModelRequest) else "Resp"
    return f"{kind}[{', '.join(parts)}]"


async def main():
    async with agent.iter(user_prompt="go") as run:
        async for node in run:
            idx = run.ctx.deps.new_message_index
            all_msgs = run.all_messages()
            new_msgs = run.new_messages()
            all_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in all_msgs)
            new_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in new_msgs)
            print(f"\n{type(node).__name__:20} new_message_index={idx}")
            print(f"  all_messages ({len(all_msgs)}): [{all_summary}]")
            print(f"  new_messages ({len(new_msgs)}): [{new_summary}]")


asyncio.run(main())
```

### Logfire Trace

_No response_

### Python, Pydantic AI & LLM client version

- Python: 3.12
- Pydantic AI: 1.41.0
- LLM provider SDK: Anthropic (not relevant)

comment.body: @DouweM What happens to the messages returned by the history processor without a run_id? When we append the next message, new_message_index is applied to it, and the previous messages will be treated as belonging to a previous run and is therefore not included.

issue.title: `new_messages()` returns wrong results when history processors prune messages from current run

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Report that something isn't working, or PR implementing a fix

issue.body:
### Initial Checks

- [x] I'm using the [latest version](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/releases/latest) of Pydantic AI
- [x] I've searched for my issue in [the issue tracker](https://github.com/pydantic/pydantic-ai/issues) before opening this issue

### Description

## Bug

When a history processor removes messages created during the current run, `new_messages()` returns incorrect results. The internal `new_message_index` becomes negative, causing Python's negative indexing to silently return a subset of messages instead of all new messages.

**Expected:** `new_messages()` returns all messages created during this run.
**Actual:** Returns only the last N messages (where N depends on how many were pruned).

## Example

Starting fresh with `new_message_index = 0` and a history processor that keeps only the last 4 messages.

**After 6 messages (pruning kicks in):**
```python
message_history = [new1, new2, new3, new4, new5, new6]
new_message_index = 0
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new3, new4, new5, new6]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = 0 - (6-4) = -2

new_messages() = message_history[-2:] = [new5, new6]  ✗ (should be all 6)
```

**After 8 messages:**
```python
message_history = [new3, new4, new5, new6, new7, new8]
new_message_index = -2
len(before_processing) = 6
message_history = processor(message_history) = [new5, new6, new7, new8]
len(after_processing) = 4
new_message_index = -2 - (6-4) = -4

new_messages() = message_history[-4:] = [new5, new6, new7, new8]  ✗
```

The index keeps decreasing: `0 → -2 → -4 → -6 → ...`

## Impact

The documented pattern is to use `new_messages()` to get messages from the current run and append them to your own copy of the history. When `new_messages()` returns incorrect results, there's no reliable way to know which messages are new - they don't have unique IDs and the length of `new_messages()` is non-monotonic.

## Root cause

The adjustment at `_agent_graph.py:495` assumes history processors only remove "old" messages from previous runs:

```python
new_message_index -= len(history_before_processing) - len(history_after_processing)
```

When processors remove messages from the current run, this overshoots and makes the index negative. There's no bounds checking here or in `run.py:160` where `new_messages()` uses the index.

## Reproduction

See attached script that demonstrates the issue with a `keep_last_4` history processor and a `FunctionModel`.


### Minimal, Reproducible Example

```Python
from pydantic_ai.models.function import AgentInfo, FunctionModel


def keep_last_4(messages: list[ModelMessage]) -> list[ModelMessage]:
    """Keep only last 4 messages."""
    return messages[-4:] if len(messages) > 4 else messages


call_count = 0


async def mock_model(messages: list[ModelMessage], info: AgentInfo) -> ModelResponse:
    global call_count
    call_count += 1
    if call_count < 5:
        return ModelResponse(parts=[ToolCallPart(tool_name="my_tool", args={"i": call_count})])
    return ModelResponse(parts=[TextPart(content="done")])


agent = Agent(
    model=FunctionModel(mock_model),
    history_processors=[keep_last_4],
)


@agent.tool
async def my_tool(ctx: RunContext[None], i: int) -> str:
    return f"ok-{i}"


def summarize_message(msg: ModelMessage) -> str:
    """One-line summary of a message."""
    from pydantic_ai.messages import ModelRequest
    parts = []
    for p in msg.parts:
        name = type(p).__name__
        if hasattr(p, "args"):
            parts.append(f"{name}({p.args})")
        elif hasattr(p, "content"):
            content = p.content[:20] if isinstance(p.content, str) else p.content
            parts.append(f"{name}({content!r})")
        else:
            parts.append(name)
    kind = "Req" if isinstance(msg, ModelRequest) else "Resp"
    return f"{kind}[{', '.join(parts)}]"


async def main():
    async with agent.iter(user_prompt="go") as run:
        async for node in run:
            idx = run.ctx.deps.new_message_index
            all_msgs = run.all_messages()
            new_msgs = run.new_messages()
            all_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in all_msgs)
            new_summary = ", ".join(summarize_message(m) for m in new_msgs)
            print(f"\n{type(node).__name__:20} new_message_index={idx}")
            print(f"  all_messages ({len(all_msgs)}): [{all_summary}]")
            print(f"  new_messages ({len(new_msgs)}): [{new_summary}]")
```

issue.title: feat(ui): add ui_source parameter to customize Chat UI source

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature request, or PR implementing a feature (enhancement)

issue.body:
## Description

Adds a `custom_cdn_url` parameter to the Web Chat UI to allow users to override the default CDN URL. This supports:
1.  **Custom CDNs**: For enterprise environments where the default CDN is blocked.
2.  **Static URLs**: For pre-deployed versions of the UI.
3.  **Local File Paths**: For working offline or with local development builds of the UI.

Fixes #3953

## Changes

- Modified `pydantic_ai/ui/_web/app.py` to accept `custom_cdn_url` and handle local file paths.
- Updated `pydantic_ai/agent/__init__.py` to expose the parameter in `Agent.to_web()`.
- Updated `pydantic_ai/_cli/web.py` and `pydantic_ai/_cli/__init__.py` to add the `--custom-cdn-url` CLI argument.
- Added comprehensive tests in `tests/test_ui_web.py` covering all new scenarios.
- Updated documentation in `docs/web.md` and `docs/cli.md`.

## Checklist

- [x] Any **AI generated code** has been reviewed line-by-line by the human PR author, who stands by it.
- [x] No **breaking changes** (parameter is optional and defaults to `None`).
- [x] **Linting and type checking** pass.
- [x] **PR title** is fit for the release changelog.
- [x] New **tests** added, maintaining 100% coverage.
- [x] Updated **documentation** for new features.

issue.title: Migrate from SPA to SSG architecture
issue.body:
## Overview
Currently, the blog is built as a Single Page Application (SPA), which has limitations for SEO and social media sharing. Meta tags and structured data are not correctly rendered in the static HTML, requiring migration to Static Site Generation (SSG).

## Goals
- Migrate the application from SPA to SSG architecture
- Ensure all blog posts are pre-rendered as static HTML files
- Properly render meta tags (Open Graph, Twitter Cards) in static HTML
- Improve SEO and social media sharing capabilities
- Maintain fast page load times and user experience

## Potential Approaches
1. **Full migration to vite-plugin-ssr or vite-react-ssg**: Complete framework-level SSG support
2. **Custom build script**: Generate static HTML files for each route during build time
3. **Hybrid approach**: Use SSG for blog posts and keep SPA for interactive sections

## Benefits
- Better SEO with pre-rendered content
- Proper meta tags for social media sharing
- Faster initial page load
- Improved Core Web Vitals scores

## Considerations
- Impact on existing routing and navigation
- Build process changes
- Deployment workflow updates
- Client-side interactivity preservation

- Navigation on mobile

issue.title: Analyze and optimize bundle size

## Description
The node_modules directory is 202MB. While chunking is configured in vite.config.ts, there is no bundle size analysis or monitoring.

## Current State
Manual chunks are defined for React, Markdown, Motion, and Icons.

## Improvements Needed
1. Add bundle analyzer: rollup-plugin-visualizer or vite-bundle-analyzer
2. Analyze and optimize largest chunks
3. Consider lazy loading heavy dependencies (e.g., framer-motion only where needed)
4. Review if all dependencies are actually needed
5. Add bundle size checks in CI

## Benefits
- Faster page loads
- Better performance
- Reduced bandwidth usage
- Improved Core Web Vitals scores

issue.title: Implement Error Boundaries for better error handling
issue.body:
## Description
The React application has no error boundaries implemented. If any component throws an error, the entire application crashes with a white screen of death.

## Impact
- Poor user experience when errors occur
- No graceful degradation
- No error reporting/logging

## Recommended Implementation
1. Create a global error boundary component
2. Add error boundaries around major sections (routes, features)
3. Implement error reporting (e.g., Sentry integration)
4. Show user-friendly error messages

## Benefits
- Better user experience during errors
- Ability to track and fix errors in production
- Application remains partially functional even when errors occur

issue.title: Add TypeScript path aliases for cleaner imports
issue.body:
## Description
The codebase uses relative imports like ../../../components/ui/Footer which become unwieldy in deeply nested files. TypeScript path aliases would improve readability and maintainability.

## Current State
import SEO from '../components/SEO';
import { SITE_CONFIG } from '../config';

## Proposed State
import SEO from '@/components/SEO';
import { SITE_CONFIG } from '@/config';

## Implementation
1. Update tsconfig.app.json with path mappings
2. Update vite.config.ts to resolve aliases
3. Refactor existing imports to use new aliases

## Benefits
- Cleaner, more maintainable imports
- Easier file refactoring
- Better developer experience

issue.title: Update .gitignore with missing common entries
issue.body:
## Description
The current .gitignore is very minimal and missing several common entries that should be excluded from version control.

## Missing Entries
- Build artifacts: *.tsbuildinfo, .vite/
- Editor configs: .vscode/, .idea/, *.swp, *.swo
- OS files: Thumbs.db (Windows)
- Test coverage: coverage/, .nyc_output/
- Logs: *.log, logs/, pnpm-debug.log*, yarn-debug.log*, yarn-error.log*
- Temporary files: .tmp/, temp/

## Priority
Medium - Quick fix, prevents accidentally committing unwanted files

issue.title: Add CI/CD Pipeline with GitHub Actions
issue.body:
## Description
Currently, there are no GitHub Actions workflows defined. This means no automated linting on PRs, no build verification before deployment, and no automated dependency updates.

## Recommended Workflows

### 1. CI Workflow
- Trigger on PRs and pushes to main
- Run npm run lint
- Run npm run build to verify builds
- Check TypeScript compilation

### 2. Dependency Updates
- Use Dependabot or Renovate
- Automatically create PRs for dependency updates

## Benefits
- Catch issues before they reach production
- Automated code quality checks
- Easier dependency management

## Priority
High - Quick win for better code quality

issue.title: Migrate from SPA to SSG architecture
issue.body:
## Overview
Currently, the blog is built as a Single Page Application (SPA), which has limitations for SEO and social media sharing. Meta tags and structured data are not correctly rendered in the static HTML, requiring migration to Static Site Generation (SSG).

## Goals
- Migrate the application from SPA to SSG architecture
- Ensure all blog posts are pre-rendered as static HTML files
- Properly render meta tags (Open Graph, Twitter Cards) in static HTML
- Improve SEO and social media sharing capabilities
- Maintain fast page load times and user experience

## Potential Approaches
1. **Full migration to vite-plugin-ssr or vite-react-ssg**: Complete framework-level SSG support
2. **Custom build script**: Generate static HTML files for each route during build time
3. **Hybrid approach**: Use SSG for blog posts and keep SPA for interactive sections

## Benefits
- Better SEO with pre-rendered content
- Proper meta tags for social media sharing
- Faster initial page load
- Improved Core Web Vitals scores

## Considerations
- Impact on existing routing and navigation
- Build process changes
- Deployment workflow updates
- Client-side interactivity preservation

issue.title: feat(macos-app): add custom namespace UI for cluster isolation
issue.body:
## Overview

Add Advanced Options section with custom namespace field that allows users to override EXO_LIBP2P_NAMESPACE environment variable. This enables splitting machines that can see each other into separate clusters.

- Added customNamespace property with UserDefaults persistence
- Added Advanced Options collapsible section with text field
- Added Save & Restart button that auto-restarts exo process
- Namespace replaces buildTag when custom value is set
- Falls back to buildTag (version) when namespace is empty

## Motivation

EXO supports multiple p2p namespaces to split up clusters via the `EXO_LIBP2P_NAMESPACE` environment variable when building from source. However, when using the macOS app, this was hardcoded to the application version, making it impossible for users to isolate machines into separate clusters without rebuilding the app.

This PR adds a UI option in the macOS app to set a custom namespace, allowing users to split machines that can see each other into multiple logical clusters.

## Changes

- Added `customNamespace` property to [ExoProcessController.swift](cci:7://file:///exo/app/EXO/EXO/ExoProcessController.swift:0:0-0:0) with UserDefaults persistence
- Added "Advanced Options" collapsible section to [ContentView.swift](cci:7://file:///exo/app/EXO/EXO/ContentView.swift:0:0-0:0) (similar to existing Debug Info section)
- Added text field for entering custom namespace with "Save & Restart" button
- Modified `computeNamespace()` to use custom namespace when set, falling back to buildTag (app version) when empty
- Button is disabled when no changes are pending
- Automatically restarts exo process when namespace is saved (if running)

## Why It Works

The implementation modifies the `makeEnvironment()` function to set `EXO_LIBP2P_NAMESPACE` using the custom value from UserDefaults. When the namespace is changed and saved:

1. User enters namespace in text field (value stored in local state)
2. Clicking "Save & Restart" writes to UserDefaults and calls `controller.restart()`
3. On next launch, `computeNamespace()` returns the custom value instead of buildTag
4. This namespace is used when creating the exo process, isolating it from other clusters

## Test Plan

### Manual Testing
**Hardware:** MacBook Air M1 8GB (macOS 26.02)

**What I tested:**
- Verified namespace field appears in Advanced Options section
- Tested entering custom namespace (e.g., "my-cluster")
- Confirmed "Save & Restart" button restarts exo process
- Verified namespace persists across app restarts (UserDefaults)
- Tested empty namespace falls back to buildTag (app version)
- Confirmed button is disabled when no changes pending

### Automated Testing
No automated tests added.
